Welcome to Calm Compass

Start understanding your mind with simple, accessible information.

How are you feeling?

Symptom Check

Assess your mental health with our quick symptom checker.

Stress

Stress is your body’s natural response to demanding situations—it’s trying to help you rise to a challenge. However, when that pressure becomes constant, it can feel like you are carrying the weight of the world without a moment to set it down.

What you can do
Anxiety

Anxiety is a feeling of unease, worry, or fear about what might happen in the future. While it can feel physically and mentally exhausting, it isn't a sign that you are broken; it is your brain trying to keep you safe, even when there is no immediate danger.

What you can do
Loneliness

Loneliness is the feeling of disconnection, feeling alone even when you are in a crowded room. Feeling this way doesn’t mean you are unlikable or destined to be isolated—it simply means you have a capacity for connection that isn't currently being met.

What you can do
Low Mood

Low mood can feel like someone turned down the volume on your life. You might feel sad, empty, or simply numb, finding it difficult to enjoy the things you usually love. This isn’t a reflection of your character or "laziness" — it is a state of emotional exhaustion.

What you can do

Calming Tools

Explore a variety of tools and techniques to help you find calm.

Stress Relievers
How: Inhale for 4 seconds, hold for 4, exhale for 4, hold for 4. Repeat 4 times.

Why: Slow, intentional breathing directly activates the parasympathetic nervous system, telling your body it's safe and instantly lowering your heart rate and blood pressure.
How:
  • 10 minute yoga session
  • Put on a favorite song and dance for the duration of the track
  • Go for a quick walk around the block, even if it's just 5 minutes out and 5 minutes back.

Why: Physical activity releases endorphins (natural mood elevators) and helps you literally "burn off" the physical energy and tension that stress creates in your muscles.
How: Put your phone on silent and place it in a drawer or another room for 15 minutes.

Why: It stops the constant flow of notifications and information, which overloads your brain, drains your mental energy and keeps the stress system engaged.
Anxiety Calmers
How: Name 5 things you see, 4 you hear, 3 you feel, 2 you smell, and 1 you taste.

Why: Engaging your senses anchors you to the present moment, interrupting anxious thoughts about the future.
How: Set aside 15 minutes daily to worry intentionally, postponing anxious thoughts until then.

Why: Knowing you have dedicated time to address worries helps your brain "let go" during the rest of the day.
How: Lie down comfortably and mentally scan your body from head to toe, noticing any areas of tension or discomfort.

Why: Shifting attention to physical sensations interrupts the mental loop of anxiety and promotes mind-body awareness.
Companionship Builders
How: Send one message to someone you haven't spoken to in a while, even just to say hello.

Why: Making small social actions builds momentum and reminds you that connection is possible, even when it feels difficult.
How: Engage in a simple care task for a living being (water a plant, feed a pet, walk someones dog).

Why: Taking responsibility for and nurturing another being is a gentle boost to purpose and connection.
How: Offer up our time or skills for a day to help a local organization or community project.

Why: Helping others provides a sense of purpose and naturally creates opportunities to connect with like-minded people.
Mood Movers
How: Spend 10-15 minutes in natural daylight, especially in the morning.

Why: Sunlight regulates your circadian rhythm and boosts serotonin production, which directly affects mood.
How: Create and listen to a playlist of songs that uplift or comfort you.

Why: Music activates the brain's reward centres, break through mental fatigue and trigger a temporary mood shift.
How: Do 2 minutes of jumping jacks, dancing, or stretching.

Why: Brief bursts of movement increase blood flow and release dopamine, providing a quick mood lift.

Quiet Wisdom

"If you get tired, learn to rest, not quit."

- Banksy

"Where there is light, there must be shadow; where there is shadow, there must be light."

- Haruki Murakami

"Do the best you can until you know better. Then when you know better, do better."

- Maya Angelou

"There is a crack in everything, that's how the light gets in."

- Leonard Cohen

"No need to hurry. No need to sparkle. No need to be anybody but oneself."

— Virginia Woolf

Still Stuck?

If you're struggling with persistent symptoms or feel overwhelmed, speaking to a mental health professional can make a real difference. Here are some resources to help you take that next step.

© 2024 Calm Compass. All rights reserved.

Professional Help Resources

Reaching out to a professional is a sign of strength, not weakness. Below you'll find trusted resources and helplines to connect you with qualified support.
  • NHS Urgent Mental Health Helpline or call 111 for urgent mental health support when it's not a life-threatening emergency
  • Samaritans for anyone struggling to cope or having thoughts of suicide
  • Crisis Text Line (Shout) for anyone in crisis who needs immediate support via text
  • NHS Mental Health Support for guidance and free NHS therapy services
  • Mind for general mental health support and information
  • Anxiety UK for support and information on anxiety disorders
  • Age UK for support for older adults experiencing loneliness or mental health issues
